title: Who is the luckiest politician in history? - Quora

response.answer_text: As of January 11, 2020, we now have our answer.  TFW you win an election with more votes than any other candidate in history only a year after getting destroyed in a previous election Tsai Ing-wen was a broken president after her “Democratic” “Progressive” Party, which has ruled Taiwan since 2016, was smothered in the local elections of November 24, 2018. Out of the 22 counties and cities up for election, the DPP only won six (down from 13 in 2014), whereas the opposition Kuomintang won 15 (up from six in 2014). To make matters worse, the KMT won by a landslide in Kaohsiung, a city in southern Taiwan that had long been considered DPP territory (think Utah or Tennessee for Republicans). The KMT candidate who won the mayoral race in Kaohsiung became the most popular politician in Taiwan. And in Taipei, where Tsai lives, the mayoral election ended with the DPP’s candidate winning only 17 percent of the vote.  Results of the 2018 Taiwanese local elections. Blue = KMT, Green= DPP It was humiliating, and Tsai knew it. Before the election, her administration had already pissed off most people by being totally incompetent. Her approval rating sunk not so long after she took office, and it didn’t get better. In line with tradition, Tsai stepped down as leader of her party, handing over her position to a nobody. She could run for a second presidential term starting in 2020, but no one thought she could win as she was polling lower than almost every possible candidate who could challenge her in the next election. Some advised Tsai not to run again, as she would lose and become the first one-term president in Taiwan’s history (I once joked that Tsai was asking for international support to fight mainland China because she ran out of supporters at home). If that wasn’t humiliating enough, William Lai Ching-te, Tsai’s former premier, threw his hat into the ring, becoming the first person from an incumbent president’s party to challenge the incumbent president. Tsai ran for reelection anyway, announcing her candidacy not to the public out in the public (as politicians usually do), but on a plane to a reporter from CNN.  Just as Tsai’s fortunes could get any worse…the KMT started discussing who they should run against Tsai in the next presidential election. Han Kuo-yu, the KMT’s candidate who had won in Kaohsiung and gained a fanatical following not only in Kaohsiung but across Taiwan as well, was pressured by his fanbase and the party to run for president. Han had just taken office as mayor of Kaohsiung, and running for president and potentially winning another election by a landslide would effectively mean abandoning the people who had voted for him and leaving the city with another “runaway mayor” (previously, it was a DPP mayor who ditched Kaohsiung to serve in Tsai’s administration). But Han decided to run for president, a decision that blew away much of the support that had helped him win in Kaohsiung. His approval rating began to drop, while Tsai’s started to increase.  Han Kuo-yu Then someone else entered the KMT presidential primary: Terry Gou, the CEO of Foxconn, who wasn’t even an active KMT party member but enjoyed some degree of grassroots support, especially from people who didn’t traditionally support the KMT. And those who thought Han is better off staying in Kaohsiung because he had just been elected. The KMT became split between Han’s fanatical supporters, Gou’s fanatical supporters, and people who were put off by both candidates because of their background. The party ultimately nominated Han, but Gou took off on his own and started rubbing shoulders with politicians outside of the KMT, taking his own fanbase with him. The KMT’s popularity decreased, Han’s popularity decreased, while Tsai’s popularity continued to increase.  Terry Gou (right) Then the protests in Hong Kong broke out. It all began with a man from Hong Kong murdering his girlfriend in Taiwan before fleeing back to Hong Kong, and Taiwan wanting him back but not getting him back because of the lack of an extradition agreement. So Hong Kong introduced a law that would allow extradition to places with which it doesn’t have an extradition agreement, which also happened to include mainland China and sparked protests that dragged on until they became violent. Unsurprisingly, the unrest was branded by the West as an uprising against China, while Tsai, whose party is against all things China, seized the opportunity to claim that the “one country, two systems” policy was not working in Hong Kong and thus wouldn’t work in Taiwan either, painting herself as a defender of “Taiwan’s sovereignty,” freedom, and democracy and her opponents as Chinese puppets. At that point, the election turned from a simple popularity contest to a race to see who is more anti-China, which Tsai is naturally better at. Tsai’s popularity kept going up; soon, she overtook Han and every other potential candidate in the polls.  Opinion polling for the 2020 Taiwanese general election - Wikipedia Then James Soong, a veteran politician who formerly belonged in the KMT but went on to form his own party, popped out of nowhere and entered the race. He didn’t take many of Han’s votes, but he was able to take some by default. And he had the backing of Terry Gou and some of his fans. Tsai’s popularity reached its peak.  James Soong On January 11, 13 months and 18 days after Tsai’s DPP was slaughtered in the local elections, the people of Taiwan went to the polls again to elect their next president and parliament. Also eligible to vote were 1.18 million first-time voters who were born during the 1990s, when government-sponsored “Taiwanization” (desinicization) began, and raised in an environment to think of themselves as Taiwanese, not Chinese. It was a sunny day. The votes were counted.  Tsai won over 8.1 million votes, more than any other presidential candidate in Taiwanese history. Her vote share is 57%, compared to 56% when she was first elected by a landslide in 2016. The DPP retained its majority in parliament, though it lost a few seats. Han, who was the most popular politician in Taiwan about a year ago, trailed by over 2 million votes. It wasn’t even close. Laugh or cry, but this will go down as one of the top 10 anime turnarounds in political history.  *airhorn sound effect*
